update.description:
A new tutorial.

It depends on the gravity compensation plugin ([PR #2733](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2733)) and thus implicitly on [PR #257](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/257) and [PR #350](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/350) as well.
update.title: Gravity compensation plugin tutorial

content.raw: I was reading through the tutorial again and noticed two typos (missing "the" and extra "."), so I fixed them in [42f5ec4](https://bitbucket.org/pchorak/gazebo_tutorials/commits/42f5ec4).
content.html: I was reading through the tutorial again and noticed two typos (missing "the" and extra "."), so I fixed them in 42f5ec4.

content.raw: I mentioned this earlier, it seems gazebo will look up at http://gazebosim.org/models for the Mass on rails model, it could be my configuration wrong though
content.html: I mentioned this earlier, it seems gazebo will look up at http://gazebosim.org/models for the Mass on rails model, it could be my configuration wrong though

content.raw:
"currently +/- 1 in Gazebo", I suppose you mean Gazebo enforces the magnitude of integral term to be  <=1.
When I tested inside Gazebo, it allows me to set any value <-1 or >1, I am not sure whether we are enforcing this limit from back end. If this is the case, let's report a bug for the GUI display, since it is displaying invalid numbers
content.html: "currently +/- 1 in Gazebo", I suppose you mean Gazebo enforces the magnitude of integral term to be <=1. When I tested inside Gazebo, it allows me to set any value <-1 or >1, I am not sure whether we are enforcing this limit from back end. If this is the case, let's report a bug for the GUI display, since it is displaying invalid numbers

content.raw: If the mass is of 0.1kg, I would prefer state at the very beginning: "we have a Mass on rail model with a cube of mass 0,1kg" Such  that users would have already known this at the P control section
content.html: If the mass is of 0.1kg, I would prefer state at the very beginning: "we have a Mass on rail model with a cube of mass 0,1kg" Such that users would have already known this at the P control section

content.raw:
Mass on rails is not available at  http://gazebosim.org/models yet. And it seems this is the default place for gazebo to look up for models when it get started with 

```
#!bash

gazebo -u worlds/gravity_compensation.world 
```
content.html:
Mass on rails is not available at http://gazebosim.org/models yet. And it seems this is the default place for gazebo to look up for models when it get started with 

gazebo -u worlds/gravity_compensation.world

content.raw:
I have added a Robonaut example to the tutorial, which adds two dependencies:

1. Updated Robonaut model [PR #262](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/262).

2. DART SdfParser fix [PR #893](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/893). (PR merged)
content.html:

  1. Updated Robonaut model PR #262.

  2. DART SdfParser fix PR #893. (PR merged)

content.raw:
Thanks Louise. This would be a great example.

The Sdf Parser is having trouble with the `<use_parent_model_frame>` tags, so I'm going to look into re-generating the model from urdf without those tags.
content.html:
Thanks Louise. This would be a great example.

The Sdf Parser is having trouble with the <use_parent_model_frame> tags, so I'm going to look into re-generating the model from urdf without those tags.

content.raw:
Robonaut always looks kinda sad when it is inserted 

![robonaut.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/3720173434-robonaut.gif)
content.html: Robonaut always looks kinda sad when it is inserted

content.raw: @scpeters I like your idea to add an example of gravity compensation with a more complex robot at the end of the tutorial. However, the PR2 appears to already hold its pose without gravity compensation (by a combination of joint damping and limits I think). Perhaps the UR10 could work as an example? I see a model for it in `gazebo_models`.
content.html: @scpeters I like your idea to add an example of gravity compensation with a more complex robot at the end of the tutorial. However, the PR2 appears to already hold its pose without gravity compensation (by a combination of joint damping and limits I think). Perhaps the UR10 could work as an example? I see a model for it in gazebo_models.

content.raw: I added a brief note about a problematic case (Pgain=10, Igain=1, Dgain=0). I was not sure about writing a whole PI control section demonstrating a problematic case. My understanding is that PI control is useful in some situations, so I did not want to give the impression that it is always a problematic case.
content.html: I added a brief note about a problematic case (Pgain=10, Igain=1, Dgain=0). I was not sure about writing a whole PI control section demonstrating a problematic case. My understanding is that PI control is useful in some situations, so I did not want to give the impression that it is always a problematic case.

content.raw: I have added instructions and an example screenshot. I left the existing plots as the python versions though because I didn't see a way to manually set the plot axis labels and legend or display more than 10s of data in the Gazebo plot utility.
content.html: I have added instructions and an example screenshot. I left the existing plots as the python versions though because I didn't see a way to manually set the plot axis labels and legend or display more than 10s of data in the Gazebo plot utility.

content.raw: Ok. Thanks!
content.html: Ok. Thanks!

update.description:
A new tutorial.

It depends on the gravity compensation plugin ([PR #2733](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2733)) and thus implicitly on [PR #257](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/257) and [PR #350](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/350) as well.
update.title: Gravity compensation plugin tutorial

content.raw: If you want to show a problematic case, you can show what happens to the oscillations if they add an I gain instead of D gain (ie. P -> PI). The oscillations are a bit bigger and aren't damped out by the small bit of natural friction in the system.
content.html: If you want to show a problematic case, you can show what happens to the oscillations if they add an I gain instead of D gain (ie. P -> PI). The oscillations are a bit bigger and aren't damped out by the small bit of natural friction in the system.

content.raw: I would add a little more explanation about how you chose these gains. It looks like you have implicitly chosen a natural frequency of 10.0 rad/s with those gains (mass = 0.1, pGain = 10.0). The natural frequency affects the speed of your response, so it's an important design parameter.
content.html: I would add a little more explanation about how you chose these gains. It looks like you have implicitly chosen a natural frequency of 10.0 rad/s with those gains (mass = 0.1, pGain = 10.0). The natural frequency affects the speed of your response, so it's an important design parameter.

content.raw: It could be helpful to add instructions for using the gazebo plotting interface to generate plots. They probably won't be as clean as the plots you made, but I think people would find it useful.
content.html: It could be helpful to add instructions for using the gazebo plotting interface to generate plots. They probably won't be as clean as the plots you made, but I think people would find it useful.
